image.altText: A headshot of Queensland Police Deputy Commissioner Steve Gollschewski

items.synopsis: More than 171,000 domestic and family violence incidents occurred in Queensland over the past year, and police are determined to improve how they respond to these cases.

title.children: Queensland's deputy police chief has seen many disasters in the job, but one 'enormous, enduring problem' outweighs them all

image.altText: Business people walk past a shiny black sign that reads "Reserve Bank of Australia".

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe says Australia's economy has entered the "third phase" in its fight against high inflation. Here's what it means for interest rates and mortgages, and whether more rate rises are likely.

title.children: The RBA says the fight against inflation has entered a new phase. Here's what it means for interest rates

image.altText: Jo O'Halloran wearing a blue top in a portrait.

items.synopsis: Medical scans cost some patients thousands in out-of-pocket expenses, and they are increasingly not covered by bulk-billing. But it's possible to save money by shopping around.

title.children: How your bills for ultrasounds, x-ray, CT and MRI could be cheaper just by crossing town

image.altText: The captain of the missing boat, Yunardi Ardi, reunites with his family

items.synopsis: Search and rescue crews are continuing to scour the waters off Aceh for the final crew member of the wooden boat that went missing on Sunday night.

title.children: Indonesian boat captain details the last moment he saw missing crew member, as search goes on

image.altText: Oyster mushrooms

items.synopsis: Australia's mushroom industry says there's no chance poisonous mushrooms could enter commercial products, as the big supermarkets say fungi sales are still going strong.

title.children: 'Absolutely impossible' for toxic mushrooms to enter Australian supply chain, growers say

image.altText: A woman and young girl leaning over railing at a home

items.synopsis: Extra funding is now available for home owners who did not meet the original criteria for government flood relief. For Helen, it means ensuring a "safe" future.

title.children: Helen has cried a lot since flood waters inundated her home in 2022. Finally they are happy tears

image.altText: A body-worn camera pinned to a brightly coloured shirt.

items.synopsis: A real estate firm in Queensland issues cameras to staff after an agent is locked inside a property during an inspection, but it's not the only sector that's seeing frustrations boil over as people struggle to survive.

title.children: Real estate agents don body-worn cameras as desperate people vent their fury

image.altText: A group of women wearing yellow and green uniforms standing in a line jump in the air celebrating

items.synopsis: Australia and England have long-standing rivalries in men's sport, but for tonight's semifinal, how relevant are these old myths to these bright young teams?

title.children: Matildas' World Cup semifinal is not about old rivalries, but new mythmakers

image.altText: Close up shot of Anthony Albanese.

items.synopsis: Boosting housing supply and reforming planning and zoning laws will be high on the agenda when national cabinet meets in Brisbane today, but the Greens are underwhelmed with renting measures that are already in place across most of the country.

title.children: National cabinet meets to discuss housing problems, with government's key policy stuck in the Senate

image.altText: A man on his phone in a yard.

items.synopsis: The financial complaints authority appears to have made inconsistent rulings on whether to give customers refunds after phishing scams, based on whether customers admit to clicking dodgy links.

title.children: Roger knew something had gone 'desperately wrong' when he checked his phone and saw 11 new payees on his banking app

image.altText: A group pf athletes in yellow shirts celebrate wildly.

items.synopsis: This is so much bigger than one team, at one point in time, in one FIFA World Cup. This is the story of triumph against a backdrop of toxic rhetoric about women and their capacity for sporting greatness, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: The Matildas have risen against a toxic backdrop of rhetoric that sneered — women can't play soccer

image.altText: Woman in orange holds pile of papers

items.synopsis: The Fulton County court clerk said the document was unofficial despite the charges listed matching the ones brought against the former US president.

title.children: Georgia's Trump indictment court admits to releasing 'test sample' document before jury vote

image.altText: an aerial photo of some solar panels

items.synopsis: The union movement warns if Australia doesn’t get on board we will miss a once-in-a-generation opportunity to become a renewable manufacturing powerhouse.

title.children: Why is Australia being compared with Namibia? Unions warn every worker should take note

image.altText: A man in a white coat touching a barley plant in a laboratory with purple light

items.synopsis: Queensland scientists say artificial intelligence can play a role in feeding the world by helping farmers produce more sustainable and profitable plants.

title.children: Could artificial intelligence help solve the world's hunger problem?

image.altText: A Mac laptop resting on a bed in the dark

items.synopsis: The eSafety commissioner is calling on the tech industry to step up protections around generative AI as the authority logs its first report of sexually explicit artificially generated imagery being used by children to bully others.

title.children: The eSafety commissioner warns tech companies to improve protections for AI users

image.altText: A lyrebird extends its feathers.

items.synopsis: Lyrebird calls echo through the forests of south-east Australia. But the passing of these songs from one generation to another is at risk.

title.children: Headphones on: Witness a lyrebird singing lesson

image.altText: an aboriginal woman wearing a beanie painting

items.synopsis: Australia's banking watchdog is investigating Westpac's sudden departure from the Northern Territory town of Tennant Creek.

title.children: Since Westpac left Tennant Creek, Mary has to travel 500km to the nearest branch

image.altText: A smiling middle-aged man with dark hair takes a selfie with a similing woman, dark blonde, red lipstick, black sleeveless top.

items.synopsis: The family of a woman who suffered a brain bleed after an accident in Thailand earlier this year has shared their grief at her death yesterday.

title.children: Woman succumbs to injuries after fall on Thailand holiday as family mourns 'kindest' person'

image.altText: A selfie with a middle-aged woman and her older parents against a pink background

items.synopsis: There are almost 140,000 people waiting for an Australian permanent parent visa, with wait times up to 40 years. But critics say there's a solution.

title.children: Sonja wants her elderly parents to join her in Australia. It's going to cost $100,000 and take 12 years

image.altText: woman looking into the camera

items.synopsis: Danielle Easey lived and died in a dangerous world. Jurors in two trials over her death have been asked to enter that drug scene, where fraud was commonplace and every day was about chasing "coin" and "rock".

title.children: 'These people are not normal': Trials over Newcastle ice addict's murder provide frightening insight into drug world

image.altText: An image of a man in red clothing and a scarf while standing in front of a painted brick wall.

items.synopsis: After quitting council earlier this year, the Greens' Jonathan Sriranganathan says he has the experience and the drive to be Brisbane's next lord mayor.

title.children: Musician who lives on a houseboat to run as Greens candidate for Brisbane lord mayor role

image.altText: Close up of a large golden coloured machine.

items.synopsis: The irradiation-testing beamline, used to test if space technology can handle the pressure of heavy particles, is the newest equipment in the ANU's Heavy Ion Accelerator Facility in Canberra.

title.children: An Australian-first space-testing beamline is set to help the national space industry skyrocket

image.altText: Amanda Rishworth wearing clear glasses and white blzaer speaking at podium into microphone.

items.synopsis: The federal government aims to reduce the number of women killed by their intimate partners by 25 per cent each year and to establish a national peak body for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander family safety.

title.children: Government aims to reduce number of women killed by intimate partners by a quarter

image.altText: A London Metropolitan Police vehicle parked outside the Russian embassy.

items.synopsis: British police say they've charged two men and a woman with identity document offences after it was reported the group were accused of spying for Russia.

title.children: Trio suspected of being Russian spies charged with identity document offences in UK

image.altText: Members of the army take part in a massive military parade to celebrate the Polish Army Day.

items.synopsis: President Andrzej Duda says the protection of Poland's eastern border is a key element of state policy, as the country borrows to buy new weapons.

title.children: Poland stages massive military parade in show of strength amid regional tensions

image.altText: A new underground metro railway line will be built between Parramatta and the Sydney CBD.

items.synopsis: The New South Wales government will hold a lower house parliamentary inquiry into Sydney Metro West timeline and cost blowouts.

title.children: NSW government denies second Sydney Metro West inquiry will be used to cancel project

image.altText: A man ina full body yellow suit and protective gear lights some wild grass on fire.

items.synopsis: Unlike the rest of the world, the Bureau of Meteorology is still not ready to say an El Niño is underway. But the outlook for spring suggests a dry season ahead, with experts warning of heightened fire risk regardless.

title.children: El Niño not officially declared but a hot, dry summer is still on the cards

image.altText: The backs of four young Afghan girls facing men perched above them who are Taliban supporters.

items.synopsis: August 15 is now known as a national celebration day for the Taliban in Afghanistan, but the UN says it's nothing worth celebrating for women.

title.children: Taliban mark two years of rule with parades in Kabul, in a nation where women's rights have eroded

image.altText: CLose up of Dorothy Angell smiling

items.synopsis: Dot Angell worked as a civilian nurse in the Vietnam War. She and other civilians suffered similar mental and physical health problems to returned soldiers and an even longer battle to have their efforts recognised.

title.children: In Vietnam nurses like Dot worked in squalid conditions during the war and their efforts long went unrecognised

image.altText: Bright red dome sits in snowy Antarctic landscape

items.synopsis: Looking like citrus peel, sections of fibreglass are being manufactured and flat-packed on the outskirts of a rural Tasmanian town, destined for Antarctica or even Hollywood.

title.children: 'Apple huts' keep scientists warm in Antarctica — they come from a little town called Penguin
